title: castle-near-borders-now-tartan
story: A CASTLE near the Borders has ordered a new tartan to be created as part of its major refurbishment.Colin Frame, , began working to bring Biggars Shieldhill Castle back to le in January after growing up around the old fortress and hosting his wedding there in .After the castle fell into disrepair, Mr Frame saw its potential as a "bespoke wedding venue", giving couples the opportunity to "take over the whole place"."I grew up in the area near the castle," Mr Frame said. "When it was repossessed , it was empty for two years."I walked in and thought it had gone downhill. The property has a lot of neglect."Mr Frame, with his team of friends and local workers, has already managed to refurbish and decorate the ground floor of the hotel, which is due to open in September.The majority of rooms have been decorated, and remaining rooms will be completed by .As part of bringing the castle back to le, Shieldhill Castle has enlisted the help of world-renowned designers, Calzeat, of Biggar, to create a unique tartan to be used across the hotel in upholstery."Weve got a rich history of Scottish history here," said Mr Frame."The ability to customise our own pattern, not to be recreated by anyone , was really important."Calzeat director Bob Galbraith was excited to work with Shieldhill on the tartan project.He said: "I feel that it is very important to collaborate on this new and exciting project with a beautul local hotel."Apart from the very important relationship between the hotel and our mill, it gives the local community a chance to see our product in situ on their doorstep."The colours and layout of the tartan turned out just as we had hoped and definitely emulates the colours of the beautul, local countryside, as well as incorporating the corporate colours of the Shieldhill."Itrsquos a classic combination."The creation of the hotels tartan, as well as its rebuilding work, were completed during lockdown.But Mr Frame was pleased to tell this newspaper that although working during lockdown has been "hugely challenging across the UK", his team has still been able to operate under the restrictions.He explained: "We wouldnt have been open now anyway ."Weve managed to work around the restrictions and undertake the refurbishments ourselves."Mr Galbraith added: "Itrsquos been extremely dficult running a business during lockdown and wersquove to adapt in ious ways to survive through these dficult times."The new collaboration with the Shieldhill has been very rewarding in more ways than one."

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: beach-boardwalk-look-blooming-great-thanks-volunteers
story: The team has been working hard over the last fortnight to create plant beds along one side of the walkway as it carries out landscaping work on the site.The boardwalk was created two years ago across the road from the holiday village to provide easy access to the beach for wheelchair users and, thanks to grants from the Walk With Scott Foundation and Beach Wheelchairs charity, two beach wheelchairs are available to borrow from Seton Sands.Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom said that the boardwalk, which also has three picnic tables and seats, had become a popular place for locals and holidaymakers all year round and members were delighted to be able to start work on its surroundings.A spokesperson said: ldquoIt was always our intention to landscape the area around the boardwalk and we are delighted that this work has finally got under way.ldquoOver the last two weeks, members of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, assisted by several enthusiastic and hard-working volunteers, have transformed one side of the boardwalk.ldquoA long raised bed has been sited alongside the pavement.ldquoA rockery has been created at the beginning of the boardwalk.ldquoSoil was provided by East Lothian Council and the areas planted up with plants suitable for the exposed situation near the sea, which will, in time, provide colour and interest for most of the summer.ldquoIn due course, we hope to make similar improvements to the other side of the boardwalk.

title: love-first-sight-couple-toast-golden-anniversary
story: Norman and Sophia Taylor enjoyed a socially distanced golden wedding anniversary, due to the Covid- restrictions, at their home on North Grange Avenue on July  with their three children.Northumbrian-born Norman, who turned  on June , met Sophia, , in Prestonpans Royal British Legion in , saying it was ldquolove at first sight and ldquoeyes over a dance floor.The pair married shortly afterwards at Prestonpans Register Office and then went on to travel the world due to Normanrsquos job as a fitter and turner, a trade he learned in the Merchant Navy.The family travelled across Britain between  and . They then stayed in Africa between  and , including Zambia, with the children attending public school in South Africa.However, Sophia started to feel homesick so moved back to Prestonpans in .Norman then got a job in Libya, working four weeks away and then being back at home for four weeks. He worked in this job for the rest of his career, retiring  years ago.During his working le, Norman was also a delivery driver.However, after his retirement he took on the role as a golf caddy at Muirfield, near Gullane.Prestonpans-born Sophia, as Cissie to her friends, worked as a barmaid, including at the former Lady Susan pub in Prestonpans.When Norman married Sophia, she had three children from a previous marriage: Richard, now aged , Charles, , and Eileen, .Their grandson Kal, described as the ldquoapple of their eye, was born in  and was ldquospoiled rotten according to Sophia.Norman and Sophia have sadly been in poor health recently, with Norman suffering a heart attack this year.However, he still makes an effort to visit the Legion in Prestonpans twice a week, every Monday and Friday.When the Legionrsquos beer garden re-opened and Norman was able to go back to his favourite bar, Richard said it was ldquothe first time I have seen a smile on his face for months.Norman says the secret to a long marriage is ldquothe we is always right.Richard added: ldquoThey are totally in love. Irsquove never seen my mum and dad fight and my dad has never risen his voice once. My dad is an absolute gentleman and they absolutely dote on each other.

title: lights-vandalised-andy-scotts-dunbear-statue
story: The steel sculpture, which features a bear standing on its hind legs and is located just off the A, near the Spott Roundabout on the edge of Dunbar, was unveiled last December.A post on social media revealed that lights next to the sculpture, which measures  feet in height, had been damaged.It reads: ldquoWe are conscious that a number of lights have been deliberately damaged at the DunBear sculpture and thanks to those for reporting this to us.ldquoWe have an engineer out looking at this.ldquoThe sculpture is very much part of the community and we would be gratefulyou see anyone damaging it that this is reported to the police.The artwork was created by Andy Scott, the same man behind The Kelpies, and is a tribute to Dunbar-born John Muir, who would go on to become a key figure in the formation of the US national parks.

title: musselburgh-library-offers-new-click-collect-service
story: This follows the introduction of the service at Haddington Library.Library members will be able to order up to six titles in advance, book a suitable collection date and pick up the order from the library.They can lsquoClick and Collectrsquo by visiting www.eastlothian.gov.uk forms form  en click_and_collectThose who are not library members or do not have internet access should contact Musselburgh Library on    and a member of staff will assist them.Opening hours for customers to collect books are: Monday-Friday, am-pm and pm-.pm Saturday, am-pm and pm-.pm.All customers are asked to wear face coverings when accessing the building on Bridge Street.Library users who currently have outstanding loans canthem to the Brunton Hall.All overdue fines have been suspended.

title: musselburgh-rugby-club-beer-garden-offers-safe-place
story: Members and guests were welcomed to the large outdoor space which has been created at its grounds at Stoneyhill.The beer garden and lsquoPickerings Patiorsquo ndash named after one of the clubrsquos main sponsors Pickerings Gin ndash is offering them a safe space to visit as the lockdown eases.A club spokesperson said: ldquoWe hope it will be a welcome facility for the local community and a permanent feature as the club moves into its centenary year in .ldquoThe club has done a lot of work getting familiar with all of the Covid government and council guidance, including full risk assessments and ensuring all staff have appropriate PPE.ldquoWe have installed sanitisers at key posts around the club and have an increased cleaning system for our toilet and bar facilities, as well as introducing systems in the bar and toilets which implement social distancing.The spokesperson added: ldquoWe really enjoyed welcoming back members and guests to our new outdoor space which we have worked hard to make sure is a safe area, given we have the luxury to use a lot of space outside the club.ldquoWe recognise peoplersquos levels of comfort will be very dferent coming outof lockdown and want to ensure we offer a safe place to visit, while also offering some form of normality, as the club has always been a welcoming and fun place to visit.ldquoThe staff have been doing a great job and we recognise it is still a learning curve for everyone, including guests.ldquoWe are looking to adapt to opening insidewe have to address any poor weather but this brings restrictions and will be thought out in more detail moving forward.The beer garden and Pickerings Patio is open Fridays pm-pm, Saturdays noon-pm and Sundays pm-pm.While walk-ins are welcome, subject to availability, bookings are recommended at the Eventbrite link via www.musselburghrfc

title: renegade-street-sweepers-bid-spruce-town
story: Called the Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, it aims to meet up on a weekly basis to take on sprucing up parts of the Honest Toun by litter picking, weeding, cleaning and general tidying up.The initiative was launched following the efforts of environment group Love Musselburgh CIC whose volunteers took on the task of painting picnic tables with seats near the Promenade.Michael Philp, of Fisherrow, who set up Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, said: ldquoI set up the group to seewe could start to arrange regular volunteer work groups to go out and do little weeding jobs and tidying up the area. I thought it would be a good thing to have a separate group of people happy to help and to concentrate on what we could do as a community rather than things we canrsquot.A Facebook page was created and has already attracted more than  members.Mr Philp said he has already been out to do some weeding around a few of the benches on the Promenade, adding: ldquoI hope we can inspire others to come and help with little projects.He said: ldquoHopefully this group will grow.ldquoWe have no money or tools yet, apart from maybe tools lying in the shed or garage, but what we have is determination and passion to make change, do things together to fix and mend what might be broken.ldquoI came to Musselburgh as a child in  and itrsquos suffered like many, many towns up and down the UK with cutbacks to many services.ldquoWe can sit and talk and debate about whorsquos to blame and say who should be doing this and who should be doing that, but it doesnrsquot solve things, so I thought we could do some little bits.ldquoOthers are doing it in other local towns with great success. Irsquod like people to post up things that they feel need attention and we will seewe can get a plan together and get some things sorted.Melanie Roccio, who set up Love Musselburgh, is supporting the group.She said: ldquoIt would be great to hear from everybody about any streets or areas around town you have noticed are in need of a little bit of TLC. Is there some overgrown shrubbery that could do with being cut back, something that could do with a fresh coat of paint or some graffiti that needs cleaned To sign up for the Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, go to www.facebook groups   refshareCouncillor Andy Forrest, Depute Provost of East Lothian, said: ldquoThis is a very welcome initiative for the town which reflects the pride many local residents have for Musselburgh. The council is always keen to support such endeavours and encourage similar groups who volunteer to enhance their local environment.Fellow ward member Councillor Katie Mackie commented: ldquoItrsquos really appreciated that local residents are volunteering to help keep Musselburgh tidy. Civic pride is important and hopefully this group can supplement the routine street cleaning and waste disposal work done by East Lothian Councilrsquos hard working waste workers. Itrsquos important there is a coordinated approach between the group and the council, and I would be happy to help facilitate thisit is required.Finally, Councillor John Williamson said: ldquoThe Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers is the latest in a number of initiatives in Musselburgh which demonstrate the growing pride in our town and a determination to make it a better place for everyone. Their work tidying and weeding at the benches on the Promenade demonstrates how easy and quick it is to make a vast improvement to an area. I wish them well with their efforts in the future and hope to be able to join in myself at some point.

title: action-packed-virtual-musselburgh-festival-proves-huge-success
story: Although the election of the  Honest Lad and Honest Lass, and the festival itself, were cancelled due to the Covid- pandemic, the local community enjoyed reminiscing about past events.The Honest Tounrsquos Association, which organises the annual festival, was determined to keep the spirit of the event alive while keeping everyone safe.Two films were shown via the associationrsquos Facebook page and Twitter feed. The first, about Kirkinrsquo Sunday, was available for viewing on what would have been Kirkinrsquo Sunday ndash July . The other was about Festival Saturday, which was shown at the end of the lsquovirtualrsquo programme on July .Festival flags were delivered to local residents by association representatives to put up outside their homes ndash a gesture which may continue for future festivals.During lockdown, photos of previous festivals from the associationrsquos archives were posted on social media and this continued during lsquovirtualrsquo festival week, with popular events in the programme displayed.A virtual fancy dress parade took place, with members of the public invited to submit photos of themselves in fancy dress at home or in past parades.The virtual dog show was a roaring success, attracting more than  entries from owners who sent in photos of their pets in  classes, giving judges Gordon Vets a dficult task.Kennedy Bosworth won the most unusual place you have found your dog categoryAnother highlight was a virtual concert co-ordinated by Julie Robinson, Honest Lass . The musical extravaganza was compegravered by Caroline Grant, Honest Lass , and saw performances from the Clark Community Choir, Tutti Orchestra, Douglas McNeill, Lorraine McBrearty, Reno Di Rolloand Fiona Grant-MacDonald.Alison Elgin, president of the Honest Tounrsquos Association, said: ldquoThe virtual festival went very, very well. People enjoyed reminiscing about years gone by.ldquoThere were lots of positive and supportive comments and feedback.She added that the coronavirus lockdown had enabled the association to develop an extensive archive of old photos and videos and added that a lsquovirtualrsquo event could run alongside future festivals.

title: playparks-revamped-new-group-formed
story: A modern playpark between Seggarsdean Court and St Martinrsquos Place was completed towards the end of last month.The pound, scheme included input from youngsters in the area, who were able to choose from two designs for the park.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was keen to see the park act as an inspiration for improving other playparks in the town.She said: ldquoThe park in Neilson Park is very good but it could still be upgraded yet again.ldquoIt is quite a number of years since it was done.A potential Friends of Haddington Playparks group could look at parks throughout the town, such as those at Riverside Drive and Davidson Terrace.Mrs Wilson was keen to see the group approach Haddington and Lammermuir Area Partnership , as well as other organisations, as potential funding sources for any revamps.She encouraged fellow community councillors to think about the potential group ahead of their next meeting.Ward councillor Shamin Akhtar highlighted that there had been similar groups set up in Ormiston and Pencaitland with great success.The local authorityrsquos spokeswoman for education and childrenrsquos wellbeing vowed to liaise with those groups to seethey could offer any advice.She offered to help in ldquoany way I can and said: ldquoWe have got lots of lovely spaces around Haddington.

title: new-long-term-parking-essential-say-north-berwick-traders
story: As part of East Lothianrsquos Council Spaces for People programme to help prevent the spread of coronavirus, bollards and planters have been placed along both sides of the road, widening the pavements and removing some parking spaces, allowing pedestrians to maintain social distancing.Nearby car parks, such as Kirk Ports and The Glebe, have been turned into  or -minute stays with nounder the scheme.David Turnbull, from Turnbullrsquos Home Hardware on High Street, said North Berwick needed more long-term parking for tourists and visitors who were likely to stay for longer than  minutes.He said: ldquoThere is now an excess of short-term and a shortage of long-term parking and, whether people were for or against the putting green [Elcho Green car park], it was a way of solving long-term parking.Council plans to construct a temporary car park at Elcho Green were put on hold after more than , people signed a petition against it.David said: ldquo[Without long-stay parking, fewer] visitors and residents are going to come [to the town centre]. There is a massive shortage of long-term spaces for these kinds of people.ldquoI can see why they want to put these measures [on the east end of High Street] in place but we need more long-term parking.David said he had visited two nearby car parks that had recently been made short term on two separate occasions and they were each one third empty.And he thought much of the opposition to the Elcho Green plan was due to misinformation about what it would consist of.David said that the new parking measures on High Street had not negatively affected his business and that there was enough short-term parking for his customers.Those at gt shop Time  Tide, however, say they have not been as busy since the measures were introduced.Staff member Lorraine, who has always lived in North Berwick, said: ldquoNorth Berwick is a seaside town and is not built for this kind of traffic.ldquoA lot of people live in flats and holiday homes nearby and they used those [long-term] car parks. These have now turned into short-term parking ndash where are these people to park now Lorraine said that restricting parking on the east end of High Street affected customers who wished to purchase heavy items such as furniture, as they would be unable to carry them to a car parked further away.She added: ldquoWersquove had to do something like a lsquosmash and grabrsquo, where we watch for the person coming and quickly put the item into their car.ldquoSome people think the area is pedestrianised and are walking on the road, whereas before the cars parked on the side of the road made people realise and they were walking on the pavement.Beverly Gilhooley, owner of pet shop Barker and Bone, said business was slightly quieter than usual but the restrictions made things ldquoa little safer, adding that she thought the short-term parking should be a permanent feature in summer.She said the restrictions suited the town during the summer, when tourism was high, but not during winter.She added that the restrictions had affected deliveries to her business, which were harder to carry out, and customers who wished to purchase heavy items.Beverly said: ldquoItrsquos a brilliant idea in summer but I hope itrsquos a more temporary thing every summer.We can keep this up for a couple of months but not for any longer.The North Berwick resident said her business could afford ldquoa little hit butthe parking restrictions continued through the winter her business would not survive.Judy Lockhart, chair of North Berwick Community Council, said the group wanted to know more about the councilrsquos future plans.She said on Monday: ldquoThe community council emailed East Lothian Council on July . . . and requested a meeting to discuss Elcho Green and have since followed our request up. To date, we have not been offered any times dates by the council.

title: tasty-chance-save-pounds-boosting-local-economy
story: Throughout August, customers heading to more than  businesses throughout the county can get a  per cent discount on food or non-alcoholic drinks to eat or drink ineach Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.Businesses from Whitecraig and Musselburgh in the west to Dunbar and Innerwick in the east are offering people the chance to make a saving on their bill through the Eat Out to Help Out scheme.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for tourism and economic development, stressed the importance of such promotions.He said: ldquoAt a time when we are encouraging folk to stay safe, support local and love East Lothian, Eat Out to Help Out is a great way of supporting many of the fantastic eateries we have throughout the county and doing our bit to help with East Lothianrsquos economic recovery. Food and drink and hospitality are key sectors and we are keen to promote as much expenditure as possible within the local economy, while enabling our local communities to stay safe.Iain Gray MSP welcomed the Scotland Loves Local campaign, which ties in with other campaigns supporting the lsquoshop localrsquo message, such as Love Local Business, run by the Courier, and East Lothian Councilrsquos Stay Safe, Shop Local.The coronavirus has caused ldquosignicant challenges for town centres, high streets and businesses throughout the county.Mr Gray encouraged people to get out and support them where possible.He said: ldquoOur small businesses, whether a pub, cafe, butcher, newsagent or a grocery shop, are the leblood of local economies across East Lothian.ldquoWhether itrsquos an emergency pint of milk, catching up with old friends in the local pub or having a meal close to home, our town centres have always been there for us.ldquoNow is the time for us to support them to get back on their feet, by thinking local first. Thatrsquos a sentiment Irsquove always been pleased to support and help promote, because East Lothian boasts some of the best local shops and businesses anywhere in Scotland.DOZENS of restaurants, hotels, cafes and other visitor attractions in the county, such as garden centres, have signed up to the Eat Out to Help Out scheme.Businesses which have registered for the initiative can be found online via: www.tax.service.gov.uk eat-out-to-help-out find-a-restaurantHere we list the premises taking part in East Lothian. title: trio-entrepreneurs-celebrate-receiving-25-000-cash-boost
story: Amee Ritchie and Jake Elliot Hook, former pupils of Ross High School in Tranent, set up Srsquowheat after developing the Srsquowheat bottle ndash a reusable double-ended water bottle made from a mix of plant materials.Hannah Gordon, from Ormiston, launched Crossroad Games CIC, which creates bespoke visual novel video games for business clients while co-creating alongside marginalised young people to develop their skills.They were among  student and graduate businesses at the university which received a portion of grant aid as part of a range of support from Santander Universities UK to help them through the Covid- pandemic.Hannah said: ldquoCrossroad Games, as a member of Queen Margaret Universityrsquos Business Innovation Zone, has been developing as a start-up community interest company that will co-design visual novel video games alongside marginalised young people. During the pandemic, it has become increasingly hard to see how the business would be able to keep developing for launch during a time of lockdown and uncertainty.ldquoThe Santander Universities UK funding given to Crossroad Games has allowed us to take a step forward instead of a hesitant one backwards. The funding will be going towards developing a visual novel game demo that will showcase our product offering. We are grateful to be given that opportunity by Santander and Queen Margaret University.Dr Richard Butt, the universityrsquos deputy principal, said: ldquoAt Queen Margaret University, we are proud to support student and graduate start-ups through our Business Innovation Zone, and, more broadly to support economic development.ldquoSo we thank Santander Universities for their generous support and commitment during this challenging time.

title: musselburgh-primary-school-extension-gets-go-ahead
story: Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, Musselburgh, plans to add a new sports hall and nursery to its already-extended building as it prepares for another increase in its school rolls.The school, which was established in , moved onto its current site in , when it was officiallyopened by Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother.However, the latest extension will mean the loss of a seven-a-side football pitch on the grounds, with plans to temporarily create a second pitch two miles away to compensate.A report by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officers said that two pitches would be lost to the planned nursery extension, with only one being replaced on another part of the site.It said that a new-a-side sports pitch would be created on council-owned land at Whitecraig, two miles from the school, next to an already-established pitch which would be lsquorealignedrsquo to allow for the addition.And it revealed that, in the long term, it was expected thatnew public use facilities at Musselburgh Grammar School would provide a permanent alternative to the lost sports pitch.The report said: ldquoSportscotland have been consulted on the application and have no objection, being satisfied that loss of a seven-a-side sports pitch at Pinkie St Peterrsquos will be mitigated by the temporary provision of an -a-side sports pitch on land at Whitecraig and the subsequent provision of a permanent synthetic grass pitch at Musselburgh Grammar School.The new nursery will also be built over the current car park access, meaning a new vehicle access will need to be built off Pinkie Road, which runs alongside the school site.Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School currently has just under  children attending school and nursery.In , it was given the go-ahead to add a single-storey extension to accommodate its growing school roll, with a secondlarger extension approved the following year.The most recent application, which received no objections, will see a new sports hall to the north of the building and nursery playrooms to the east.There will also be additional car parking spaces and cycle park facilities.

title: mcdonalds-bid-signs-service-station-site
story: Three planning applications have been submitted by the fast food giant to East Lothian Council for the former Raceland site, near Gladsmuir.The site, north of the A, already has the go-ahead to be turned into a roadside service station.The latest set of proposals show McDonaldrsquos would be located beside the B, which connects Macmerry and Gladsmuir with Longniddry.Drawings show a iety of signs to highlight the fast food chain.Go-kart centre Raceland closed in January , with the plans from Euro Garages Ltd being given the go-ahead by the councilrsquos planning committee just over  months later.The plans show two drive-thru restaurants, as well as a drive-thru coffee shop and a petrol station, with shop.When plans were approved, it was claimed that more than  jobs could be created on the site.Earlier this spring, further advertising consent plans were lodged by Euro Garages.Those proposals, which have been approved, included a totem-pole style sign which featured logos for McDonaldrsquos, Greggs, Subway, Starbucks and KFC.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed the businesses listed in the image could change.The latest set of plans show ious signs for McDonaldrsquos, which currently has one other restaurant in East Lothian, beside Dunbarrsquos Asda store.Separate plans are also being considered for a McDonaldrsquos in the car park at Musselburghrsquos Tesco store.Meanwhile, Greggs has branches in Haddington, Musselburgh, North Berwick, Prestonpans and Tranent.Subway can be found in Haddington and Musselburgh, while Starbucks and KFC are yet to open a branch in the county.

title: call-extend-20mph-limit-past-seton-sands
story: East Lothian Council has introduced lower speed limits in many towns and villages ndash including Cockenzie and Port Seton ndash as part of a project to make the streets safer for pedestrians and the increased number of cyclists who are being seen out and about.It is also creating a temporary cycle path between Cockenzie and Port Seton and Prestonpans which will run along the north side of the B coast road.Community councils in these areas have welcomed these changes, which were announced after the local authority received pound.million in funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People initiative.However, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council has called for its mph road speed limit to be extended to include the section of the B at Seton Sands Holiday Village, to the immediate east of Port Seton, which has been the scene of tragic road accidents in the past.Bryan Hickman, community council chairman, said while some concerns had been raised on social media about the money being spent on measures and their temporary nature, the majority of people commenting supported the changes.He said: ldquoMost people, including the community council, are in agreement. Any work that makes the roads safer for pedestrians and cyclists must be welcomed and supported.ldquoIt is felt, however, that the mph zone needs to be extended beyond Seton Sands holiday camp.ldquoThis stretch of road is very prone to speeding and has had a number of accidents, some unfortunately fatal.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, said they, along with neighbouring community councils in Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry, had been campaigning for lower speed limits around their communities.And he said the introduction of the three-metre wide cycle lane on the coast road would be welcomed by cyclists and motorists alike.He said: ldquoWith the huge increase in cyclists on our local roads and shoppers having to queue on pavements measures aimed at slowing the speed of traffic in the town are to be welcomed.ldquoThe three community councils in the Preston Seton Gosford ward have been campaigning to get speed limits lowered on the roads around the local towns and villages and hopefully this will also be introduced by East Lothian Council.ldquoThe dedicated cycle route between Prestonpans and Cockenzie will be particularly welcomed by local children who have taken to their bikes during the pandemic. The two-way cycle path will also be appreciated by motorists who have been getting frustrated at the signicant increase of cyclists using the coast road.Additional plans under Spaces for People include installing, in the autumn, electric bike hire stations featuring eight e-bikes at two locations in Prestonpans and one in Cockenzie in autumn.

title: former-butcher-shop-town-centre-sale

title: fundraising-cyclist-knows-east-lothian-z
story: Peter Hardie, from Tranent, took a town, village or tourist attraction for each letter of the alphabet and cycled between each one in alphabetical order.He completed the challenge on Friday, July , cycling  miles in  hours and  minutes, a faster time than expected.He initially expected to cycle  miles but, after finding some shortcuts, he shaved eight miles off his total distance.He left his house in the townrsquos Windygoul area at .am, finishing at the zebra crossing near Tranentrsquos Co-op store at .pm.Apart from grass getting stuck in the chain of his mountain bike, the ride went off without a hitch and both man and bike made it to the finishing line in one piece, enjoying the views along the way.Peter told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom still mentally tired. Afterwards I could walk round the corner but I couldnrsquot be bothered.ldquoI got lucky that I didnrsquot get any injuries. I think all my preparation worked. about how long I would be out for.ldquoI just thought thatI can find a place in Haddington [that starts with the letter lsquoIrsquo] then that could save a lot of miles and give myself a bit of easiness.Peter said that the challenge was also inspired by a person who had travelled on all of the buses in Edinburgh, a challenge that ldquoalways stayed in my head.He raised money for the gone.On doing the challenge again but potentially with dferent places, Peter said that he had not thought about it but was considering doing a dferent cycling challenge.To support Peter, visit title: artist-harry-king-festival-launches-shop-local-scheme
story: While festival organisers have teamed up with businesses in North Berwick to encourage residents to lsquoshop localrsquo.More than  pupils from throughout East Lothianrsquos schools submitted colourful drawings for a competition to create the programmersquos cover.Originally, the plan was for the winning entry to be used on the cover of this yearrsquos programme. We found it really tricky to choose a winner but Harryrsquos colourful picture of North Berwick stood out for its attention to detail and quirky touches.Organisers are also running a prize draw, which takes place over the planned dates this yearrsquos festival, August -, to encourage people to shop local.Shoppers who spend more than pound in several North Berwick shops can enter the prize draw with a chance of winning a pound Fringe by the Sea package, including pound worth of tickets for next yearrsquos event, pound food and drink vouchers and pound North Berwick gt vouchers.To enter, shoppers must complete a postcard from any of the participating stores and hand it in before the closing date ndash the stores will display posters featuring the shortlisted artwork from the schools competition.The stores currently taking part are: Andersonrsquos Quality Butchers, Barker  Bone, Cake Cafeacute, Coastal Kids, Emma Combe Hair, etchellip, Fingers  Thumbs Arts  Craft Centre, Heart  Sole, Meg Maitland, No  Hotel  Bistro, Rock  Bird, Scottish Seabird Centre, Steampunk Coffee, The Herringbone and Westgate Gallery.Jackie added: ldquoWe have many fantastic businesses in North Berwick and wersquore encouraging people to shop local and support the livelihoods of our traders and keep the town thriving.Those looking for a taste of the festival can enjoy a pop-up photography exhibition in the Robert Louis Stevenson garden at the far east end of High Street. title: scotlands-schools-return-7-key-points-parents-pupils-know
story: Schools across the country are set to reopen their doors full-time from August , with some local authorities opting for blended method until August .It comes as a recent survey suggests almost half of teachers do not think it is safe for pupils to .The NASUWT union questioned  teachers ahead of schools reopening this week.The survey found teachers are anxious about going back to work and have not been given enough information or time to prepare.A total of % of those questioned do not think it will be safe for pupils to , with % uncertain.But what should parents and pupils know ahead of the t to the classroom Social distancing:There should be no requirement for physical distancing between pupils of any age However where possible, secondary school pupils should physically distance where possible - being asked to refrain from close contact including hugs and high-fives.Pupils should not sit face-to-face at shared desks.Adults teahcers will be expected to stay m from pupils other adults wherever possible.If yoursquore worried about your child going back to the classroom, National Clinical Director @JasonLeitch has explained what schools and nurseries are doing to keep children safe and what you can expect when they get there.Find out more ## https:t.co MurxrqrqI pic sVMvVUFace coverings:PPE will not be needed in most schools, unless required by a risk assessment.Pupils will not be required to wear a face covering, but anyone wishing to do so should be allowed to.Where staff cannot maintain a m distance and are interacting face-to-face for a sustained period of around  minutes or more, a face covering should be worn.A changed day:Some schools and local authorities may opt for staggered start and end times to allow for less crowding as parents drop of and collect their children. Your local authority should contact you regarding this.Likewise, lunch hours and class times may be staggered to allow for less crowding in corridors and canteens.Assemblies will also be cancelled, with PE classes only taking place outdoors.School transport:Dedicated school transport should be treated as an extension of the school estate - meaningenhanced cleaning ofvehicles, and the inclusion of hand sanitising before boarding.Distancing between pupils on dedicated school transport is not required ndash but adults should remain one-metre apart from others.Pupils on school transport do not need to wear face coverings, but adults should.Anyone travelling to school on public transport must follow the public transport guidance on face coverings and distancing.Pupils will not need to distance on school busesHygiene:A ldquorigorous approach to environment cleaning must be implemented to prevent the virus from spreading, according to the Scottish Government.This means pupils may not be allowed to bring in as many belongings as before.Enhanced hygiene measures must be practiced, including:Coronavirus testing:The Scottish Government says arrangements are in place to monitor developments and allow for a ldquorapid response to any cases of the virus.They say this includes ldquoenhanced surveillance arrangements, test and protect and outbreak management.Contingency plans:In the event of a national or local outbreak, schools may need to introduce their plans for blended learning or close temporarily to help control transmission.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government websitehere.

title: sqa-exams-u-turn---know-far-john-swinney-might-change
story: The Deputy First Minister is to set out a series of seps to address concerns on Tuesday, amid mounting criticism over the downgrading of pupilsrsquo results.But what is the anger all about  And what has John Swinney said about a potential U-turn Here, we detail out everything you need to know about the SQA exam results saga:Why are people annoyed With no exams sat this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, the Scottish Qualications Authority applied a methodology that saw grades estimated by teachers downgraded.Pass rates for pupils in the most deprived data zones were reduced by .% in comparison with .% for pupils from the most affluent backgrounds.Exams were unable to go ahead this yearWhat is the Scottish Government doing about it Education Secretary John Swinney is expect to perform a major U-turn in a bid to sort out the current situation.The Courier reports that Mr Swinney is set to announce changes to the grades appeals process for pupils, with officials said to be examining ways to automatically review the results of downgraded pupils without each having to lodge an inidual appeal.On #SQAResults I have heard the anger of students who feel their hard work has been taken away from them and I am determined to address it.These are unprecedented times and as we have said throughout this pandemic, we will not get everything right first time.In a statement released on Sunday, Mr Swinney said: ldquoI have heard the anger of students who feel their hard work has been taken away from them and I am determined to address it.ldquoThese are unprecedented times and as we have said throughout this pandemic, we will not get everything right first time."Every student deserves a grade that reflects the work they have done, and that is what I want to achieve.ldquoI have been engaged in detailed discussions over the way forward and I know that we need to act and act quickly to give certainty to our young people.ldquoI will set out on Tuesday how we intend to achieve that.How have pupils reacted to the results Across the country pupils took to protest the results both in person and through an online petition.So far nearly , people have signed the petition, which hit out at what it called a ldquoclassist marking scheme.More than , people have signed a petitionPetition founder Sarah McLauchlan said: ldquoResults should be based off personal performance and personal performance only.ldquoEvery child is dferent, so assuming just because they are from a deprived area they wonrsquot do as well and children from privileged areas will excel is biased and unfair.ldquoIt is completely unacceptable and wrong, especially when class should not be a basis for results which impact the rest of a childrsquos le.The petition can be found here.What have political opponents said Scottish Labour will this week table a motion of no confidence in Mr Swinney, who is also the Deputy First Minister, which will be supported by the Scottish Conservatives.Earlier, Lord McConnell, the former Labour first minister, issued a warning to Nicola Sturgeon and John Swinney over the exam results chaos, saying ldquoget it fixed or go.Lord McConnell said the fiasco which saw , pupilsrsquo results downgraded is ldquonot good enough for Scotland.And writing in the Sunday Times, former SNP minister Alex Neil said the Scottish Government ldquomust reverse the decisions it made about examination results that saw the poorest children in many of the most deprived areas downgraded on the altar of a manufactured algorithm prepared in secret.A Scottish Government spokesman said about three-quarters ndash , ndash of all grade estimates required no adjustment, adding that the SQA results ldquoshow a narrowing of the gap between the most and least disadvantaged young people attaining grades AndashC compared to last year, and to a level below the average for the last four years.Pupils protesting the exams scandalScottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross said First Minister Nicola Sturgeon must remove Mr Swinney, saying she either ldquobacks Scotlandrsquos pupils or she backs an education secretary that has presided over this exams fiasco.Scottish Labourrsquos education spokesman, Iain Gray, said Mr Swinney ldquoneeds to go, adding: ldquoItrsquos taken John Swinney five days to even admit this fiasco is his responsibility. The threat of a no-confidence motion has seen him finally accept the fact that he got this badly wrong.The Scottish Greens and Liberal Democrats have not saidthey will back the no-confidence motion.Scottish Greens education spokesman Ross Greer said he welcomed John Swinneyrsquos ldquoadmission that the Scottish Government got this badly wrong.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoAn admission of error is step one in resolving this major issue but the detailed solution is what matters.ldquoWhy we ever got into this sorry state is a question that needs answered too.

story: UntilAugust ,onMondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays, restaurantsparticipating in the UK Governments Eat Out to Help Out scheme will offer half pricefoodand non-alcoholic drinks up to a total value of pound per person.Alcoholic drinks and service charges are excluded from the offer.Restaurants are offering % off foodThe initiative, launched by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, is encouraging peopleto support the hospitality industry by getting back to having meals out ascoronaviruslockdown measures are eased.In the first week more than  million meals were purchased as part of the new initiative.The Treasury said it had been sent ,, claims for inidual meals from restaurants as part of the Eat Out to Help Out programme.The interactive map showing locations within an area of GlasgowIt means that a maximum of pound. million can have been claimed in the first week of the scheme, which runs on every Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in August.The Treasury has put aside pound million to pay for the programme.The around , restaurants that have signed up to the Eat Out scheme so far take off % of a customerrsquos bill at the till and are reimbursed by the Treasury.How does it work You donrsquot need a voucher to use the scheme and you can use it at the same time as other offers and discounts. title: scotlands-schools-return-four-simple-tips-help-young-people-sleep
story: For thousands of people across the country, this week marks their first time in a classroom since March.And with the pressures of ing to school and the drastic change from lockdown le, many might find it hard to fall asleep.Sleep Scotland, a charity organisation working to address sleep issues in children and young people, says that lockdown has resulted in youngsters experiencing poor sleep.Schools are back in Scotland this weekldquoThere are many factors affecting sleep but a crucial one is our Circadian rhythms, they said.ldquoOur circadian rhythms are the physical, mental and behavioural changes that follow a daily cycle.ldquoNearly every cell and tissue has its own rhythm, controlled by our biological clocks.ldquoIf our biological clocks are disrupted it can affect our circadian rhythms, and these changes have been linked to lots of other issues, including over activity, depression and obesity.They have set out four important factors for parents to pay attention to, in order to get your childrsquos sleep back on track for theto school.Light#According to Sleep Scotland exposure to light at the wrong time can sht sleep and wakefulness - causing your brain to be alert.Their guidance says: "Make sure your room at bedtime is dark. Reduce light from the hall. Make sure there are no electronics sending out light e.g. a digital alarm clock with a lit display, sleep buttons on equipment etc."You may want to put black curtains at the window or wear an eye mask to limit the light getting into the eye."Sleep Scotland suggests wearing an eye maskOn the other end, you should also get lots of light in the morning to help you feel awake and alert.They added: "Exposure to light at the right time helps keep the circadian clock on the correct time schedule."Make sure you open the curtains and turn on the lightsyou need to. Going for a walk is a great way to start the day."RoutineIt is only natural that during lockdown many of us have found that we have lost our routine and have been staying up later and lying in bed longer in the morning.Sleep Scotland said: "Your body clock works best when you stick to a schedule."In an ideal world, yoursquoll go to sleep and wake up within a half hour of the same time each day, even on weekends."The routines of the day also give us powerful signals and demands that the body remain alert for certain tasks and events."Regular waking and bed times, alongside regular meal times are very important for regulating your body and its s."Sleep PressureSleep pressure is the term used to describe the feeling of tiredness we have, due to the activity we undertake through the day.Sleep Scotland say it is important to be active in order to make sure we create the sleep pressure and drowsiness that will help us to fall asleep.They argue that having a nap can relieve our sleep pressure, meaning we find it harder to fall asleep at bedtime.Take a tech breakNaturally during lockdown many of us have resorted to using screens to help keep us entertained,to work and to socialise with friends.And while most modern tech has a blue light filter, it does not filter all light.More importantly, the things you do online are usually things that stimulate your brain and make it harder to turn off when you get into bed.Therefore, Sleep Scotland say you should unplug from all screens at least an hour before bedtime.They added: "In the hour before bed, ensure you focus on doing things that are calming."Now is the time to read, draw, do some calming exercises, have a warm bath etchellip"

title: john-swinneys-sqa-u-turn-seven-things-need-know
story: The Education Secretary announced the U-turn after a backlash from students who felt they had been treated unfairly by the Scottish Qualications Authoritywhen it recalculated their results.John Swinney said he knew that the apology was not enough, and action would need to be taken to recty the situation.Here are seven things you need to know from his announcement:Teachers estimates to be restored:All downgraded marks will be restored and new certicates sent out.Mr Swinney said: ldquoUsing powers available to me in the EducationAct , I am today directing the SQA to re-issue those awards based solely on teacher or lecturer judgment.ldquoSchools will be able to confirm the estimates they provided for pupils to those that are ing to school this week and next.ldquoThe SQA will issue fresh certicates to affected candidates as soon as possible and, importantly, will inform Ucas and other admission bodies of the new grades as soon as practical in the coming days to allow for applications to college and university to be progressed.What are the new Scottish results The A to C attainment rates for National , Higher and Advanced Higher are now expected to jump by ., . and . percentage points compared to , rising to .%, .% and .% respectively.Will any grades be lowered The Education Secretary has said that no grades which were moderated to give an increased mark will be reduced.When will the results be given John Swinney said that schools will be able to confirm the estimates they provided for pupils to those that are ing to school this week and next.He added: "The SQA will issue fresh certicates to affected candidates as soon as possible and, importantly, will inform UCAS and other admission bodies of the new grades as soon as practical in the coming days to allow for applications to college and university to be progressed.Will all students get into their course He has said that due to the unique circumstances of this situation the Scottish Government ldquowill make provision for enough places in universities and colleges to ensure that no one is crowded out of a place they would otherwise have been awarded."WhatI have already appealed Pupils, who title: perseid-meteor-shower-2020-peak-week-best-time-spot
story: If skies are clear, the display of celestial fireworks should be visible across the UK from about midnight tonightuntil .am UK time on Thursday, August  - according to astronomers at Royal Observatory Greenwich.What are the Perseids The astronomical event is associated with the dusty debris left by Comet Swt-Tuttle, which orbits the sun once every  years.The meteoroids from the comet, mostly no bigger than a grain of sand, burn up as they hit the Earthrsquos atmosphere at  miles per second to produce a shooting stream of light in the sky.Peak temperatures can reach anywhere from ,C to ,C as they speed across the sky.The meteors are called Perseids because they seem to dart out of the constellation Perseus.The meteor shower began on July  and will continue to be visible until August .What have astronomers said Anna Ross, an astronomer at the Royal Observatory Greenwich, said the best time to spot the meteors is between midnight and .am on Thursday, when up to  meteors or ldquoshooting stars will be visible per hour, which is more than one every second.She told the PA news agency: ldquoThis makes the Perseids one of the most impressive meteor showers of the year.ldquoDuring the peak night of the shower, you will be able to find it in the north-east of the sky, getting higher throughout the night.ldquoYou donrsquot have to be able to see Perseus to spot meteors, however, as they will be moving away from the radiant across the whole sky in every direction.To make the most of the meteors, Ms Ross said observers should avoid well-lit and built-up areas and try to find an unobstructed view to the east.She added: ldquoFind a dark area and allow around  minutes for your eyes adapt to the dark.ldquoAs meteors move quite fast across the sky itrsquos best to look up without using telescopes or binoculars so you can see as much of the sky as possible.How regular will the meteors be The Perseids are one of the more active meteor showers on stargazersrsquo calendars, producing an average of between  and  shooting stars an hour at their peak.The shower in rsquos was especially active, delivering up to  meteors an hour at its height.While the shooting stars this year wonrsquot be quite as regular, stargazers can still expect to see around  of them an hour.Do I need special equipment to see the Perseids Meteor showers are typically visible with the naked eye, so no special equipment is needed, but those in rural areas with minimal light pollution will have a clearer view.Heading out to a dark spot is the best plan of action, but stargazers should allow around  minutes for their eyes to become accustomed to the dark.Patience is also a virtue, with shooting stars tending to appear in clusters, followed by a lull.The meteors will appear to come from the direction of the Perseus constellation in the north eastern part of the sky, although they should be visible from any point.A cloudy night could still scupper your chances of spotting any meteors, however, so keep your eye on weather forecasts.

title: new-head-education-named
story: Ms Brown is currently the chief operating officer for education with the local authority and will take the place of Fiona Robertson, who moved to a new post with Midlothian Council at the start of the year.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoLesley has a strong track record and will play a vital leadership role. This is particularly important at a time when East Lothian is one of Scotlandrsquos fastest growing areas, with a continued focus on ensuring all children and young people get the best start in le, enabling them to enjoy being young, and to grow and develop in a safe, supportive environment."I would like to congratulate Lesley on her appointment. I look forward to working with her.Ms Brown joined East Lothian Council in  from Education Scotland. Her start date for her new role has still to be confirmed.Monica Patterson, council chief executive, said: "I would like to congratulate Lesley and look forward to working with her as she leads the development of services and partnerships that will enable children and young people in East Lothian to live safe, healthier, more active and independent lives."

title: east-lothian-council-musselburgh-racecourse-redundancies
story: In a move described by union officials as a ldquoworrying indication for the future, talks with a number of staff are being held.It is understood that three of the five ground staff who look after the course are being axed, leaving just two and the head groundsman.Racecourse manager Bill Farnsworth confirmed that redundancy talks were being held and pointed to the devastating impact of Covid- on the industry and Musselburghrsquos operations.However, GMB Scotland, which oversaw negotiations with East Lothian Council and Chester when the local authority brought them in to operate the racecourse, said it believed more options should have been considered.And it questioned how the award-winning course could keep up standardsthe workers involved were reduced so drastically.Benny Rankin, GMB Scotland organiser, said: ldquoWe are doing all we can to assist our members affected by these redundancies but there is no denying itrsquos a worrying indication for the future of this historic racecourse.ldquoWe believe that Chester havenrsquot explored all possible options to protect the employment of the existing workforce, including the use of the Government furlough scheme until its deadline, and this looks like the easy option rather than the right thing to do for the long-term.ldquoWe struggle to see how Musselburghrsquos five-star status can be sustainedsome of the workers who help make it what it is are losing their livelihoods, and it poses questions of the Chester management over their vision for the future of this course.Musselburgh Racecourse was run jointly by East Lothian Council and Lothians Racing Syndicate for more than a decade under the Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee.However, issues within the committee led to the British Horseracing Authority demanding an independent inquiry into its governance, which revealed a toxic relationship had developed between the two parties.The council set up Musselburgh Racing Associated Committeendash a new governance body ndash to oversee it as it sought a third-party operator to take over the management of the course.Staff at the racecourse at that point became council employees.When Chester took over on June , they transferred to the company.Mr Farnsworth said that the course finances had been hit by lockdown and, even when racing resumed behind closed doors, it was with no spectators or hospitality.He said: ldquoIt would be inappropriate to comment on the details but, like every racecourse in the country, we are having to review operational costs across the business in light of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoThe reality is that since we resumed racing behind closed doors on June , we are a racecourse which is now racing again but without spectators, without hospitality revenues and with reduced sponsorship and media rights income.ldquoThe racecourse is unable to carry on as normal.ldquoLike every other business, be it in the sports, leisure, tourism, retail, professional services or industrial sectors, we are having to review everything we do in order to have a sustainable business, so that we can recover from the coronavirus pandemic.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, described the redundancies as ldquodeeply concerning.He said: ldquoThe change of ownership was meant to secure the course and the jobs, not threaten them.ldquoThese are dficult times but staff have maintained a marvellous facility before and during the crisis.ldquoThey are entitled to be treated better.ldquoIrsquoll be seeking assurances from the new management.

title: patrols-carried-human-waste-left-campers
story: Problems surrounding irresponsible campers were highlighted last month after reports of illegal fires being started and people leaving behind ldquotoilet paper and human waste.The disgusting image at Tyninghame Beach was highlighted by the countyrsquos countryside rangers.On Friday evening, with temperatures soaring across the country, they were joined by police officers in patrolling the beach.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed future patrols would also be carried out when the site was expected to be busy.She said: ldquoWe work closely with Police Scotland and other partners to manage responsible access to our coastal sites which includes matters such as parking capacity, wild camping and anti-social behaviour.ldquoOver the past months our countryside rangers have been carrying out patrols in and around our coastal sites engaging in particular with groups of campers.ldquoOn Friday, they were joined by colleagues from Police Scotland.ldquoThe purpose of these patrols is to provide information on responsible wild camping and behaviour in our countryside sites, and to discourage illegal camping and anti-social behaviour especially when it involves groups.ldquoWe intend to conduct these joint patrols over the busier weekends.Last month, countryside rangers revealed there had been an ldquounprecedented number of visitors along the East Lothian coast.The number was so large that some coastal car parks, including those at Tyninghame, Gullane and Yellowcraig, had to be closed.On one Saturday last month,  tents were found at Tyninghame, which equated to about  people camping in an area with no toilet facilities.Across East Lothian, more than  tents were found along the coastline.

title: delight-east-lothian-pupils-exam-results-u-turn
story: Exams were cancelled this year for students because of the coronavirus pandemic and teachers were asked to submit expected grades for each senior pupil based on prelim results and course work.However, the Scottish Qualications Authorityreviewed the submissions and using a lsquostatistical modelrsquo, which took into account the historic exam performances of schools, downgraded thousands of submitted grades, causing a national outrage.In East Lothian, , pupils received some grades which had been marked down.Only  of the , young people who were due to sit SQA exams had any of their final grades increased.The results dropped through letterboxes last Tuesday and sparked a furious backlash from students who received lower grades than expected.Erin Campbell, , Member of the Scottish Youth Parliamentfor Musselburgh, said many friends had been left worried and scared after the initial results came out, warning that the fiasco had been ldquobad for their mental health.Erin, who was a sixth-year student at Musselburgh Grammar School, said: ldquoOn a personal level, I was lucky to receive the results that I needed in order to move on to university however, I am aware of a lot of young people, including close friends, who were left scared and worried after not receiving a conditional offer to uni that was reliant on these results.ldquoThis badly impacted their mental health, particularly during the period of uncertainty before [Education Secretary] John Swinneyrsquos announcement [on Tuesday].Student protests were held in Glasgow and Edinburgh and politicians piled on pressure for the Scottish Government to step in and overturn the results.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray, Labourrsquos education spokesperson, called on Mr Swinney to resign after he initially backed the modied results before bending under pressure and telling the Scottish Parliament on Tuesday the Scottish Government had got it wrong.Mr Swinney said it was ldquodeeply regrettable we got this wrong and ordered the SQA to amend awards which had been marked down back to the submitted grade provided by teachers and reissue them.Mr Gray said Mr Swinney had spent five days defending the results before changing his position on Tuesday, asking him: ldquoWhy did he defend the results of this moderation for five days  Why did he leave these young people twisting in the wind for a week, hopes and aspirations in shreds Speaking after the decision, Mr Gray said: ldquoGiven the scale of the exam results scandal, it was inevitable that many local students would have been affected. I have certainly had a number of young people and parents contacting me over the last week to express their concerns about their grades being adjusted down by the SQA and the impact it might have on their futures.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos u-turn will bring relief to these worried young people and their families as they will now see their estimated results reinstated.ldquoHowever, the fact remains they should not have had to experience this worry and uncertainty in the first place. The Education Secretary has let them down and should be held accountable for this fiasco.Schools in East Lothian were yesterdaycontacting pupils who had been affected to let them know they would receive new awards.Across the county, , grades were submitted to the SQA for pupils at the end of May across National , Higher and Advanced Higher level by their teachers.In total, , were acceptedwith  adjusted upand ,adjusted down.In terms of pupils who were due to sit the exams, the council said just over  per cent saw at least one grade marked down.Councillor Shamin Akhtar , cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that John Swinney has finally decided to do the right thing for pupils on the exam results fiasco.ldquoYoung people have faced a very tough and stressful time already and this is something they should never have had to go through.ldquoSchool staff worked extremely hard to submit grades for their pupils to the SQA and the adjustments undermined their professional judgement.ldquoThis u-turn is a victory for young people who have led the campaign against the unfair results and should be commended for standing up for their rights.And Councillor Craig Hoy , a member of East Lothianrsquos education committee, said: ldquoI am delighted that grades have been restored to hardworking pupils in East Lothian who faced huge uncertainty over the last week for no good reason.ldquoEveryone can see that John Swinney has presided over a litany of failures, any one of which could have been a resignation issue on its own.ldquoThe SNP defended their appalling grading system to the hilt, even after it became clear that pupils, parents and teachers had no confidence in the system.On Monday, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon issued an apology to students across the country who had been marked down by the SQA.She said: ldquoOur concern, which was to make sure the grades young people got were as valid as in any other year, perhaps led us to think too much about the overall system and not enough about the inidual pupil.ldquoThat has meant too many students feel they have lost out on grades they should have had, and that that has happened not as a result of anything they have done but a statistical model or algorithm.ldquoDespite our best intentions, I do acknowledge that we did not get this right and I am sorry.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council welcomed the u-turn, adding: ldquoThroughout this process our schools have sought to represent the academic achievements of our young people in a way that provided a fair and accurate reflection of attainment using the guidance and methodology provided by the SQA.ldquoThe announcement by the Education Secretary will be welcomed by young people who saw their results downgraded, and by our teachers and schools who used their professional judgement when providing grade estimates.East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskillpledged his support to headteachers in a letter at the end of last week after the original results came out.He said: ldquoI welcome the Scottish Governmentrsquos announcement.ldquoAs I said last week in a letter to East Lothianrsquos headteachers, I believe the people best placed to know about pupils are those overseeing and working alongside them during their academic journeys.ldquoThis decision is the right one, and I want to send my congratulations to all students in East Lothian for the work they have achieved both before and during this pandemic, as well as a huge thanks to the teachers and school support staff who have worked so hard over the last few months.

title: betrayal-claim-mcdonalds-musselburgh-recommended-approval
story: In a letter to the Courier, Fraser McAllister hit out at their ldquoillogical recommendation which,approved by councillors at an online meeting next week, would grant permission for a restaurant to be created in the car park of the Tesco store off Olivebank Road.He claimed that the drive-thru, which would operate  hours a day, seven days a week, would be ldquonext to the most congested roundabout in the county.The former SNP councillor for Musselburgh West said: ldquoTragically,  local objectors and , petitioners have less value than the share value of these gigantic corporations.He called on councillors on the planning committee, which will debate the proposal on Tuesday, to halt the ldquobetrayal.Mr McAllister also lodged a formal objection, citing a range of concerns including traffic congestion, pollution, litter, obesity, residential amenity and economic damage.He claimed: ldquoThe custom predicted for this -hour McDonaldrsquos drive-thru and the intensity of the declared deliveries needed to service it are on an industrial scale. The impact on Olivebank Road would be truly calamitous.The plan will go before a lsquovirtualrsquo meeting of the planning committee after being called off the delegated list by ward councillor Stuart Currie because of the level of local concern.He said: ldquoI have called this application off the list to ensure that all the concerns raised by local residents are discussed and elected members can understand not only the strength of feeling but also the planning issues that exist as a result of this application.Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council has lodged an objection, citing traffic congestion, emissions, and the facilityrsquos close proximity to local schools as concerns.A public campaign lsquoNo McDonaldrsquos in Musselburghrsquo was also launched in a bid to halt the plan, highlighting concerns such as increased traffic congestion, litter and air pollution.The planning report stated that there were  written representations to the application and, of these,  were objections.It said: ldquoThe councilrsquos road services advise they accept the conclusions of the traffic network modelling exercise, that the traffic impact associated with the proposed development would be minimal and there would be no adverse impact on the operation of the local highway network.ldquoMany written objections are made on the grounds of the proximity of the proposed drive-thru restaurant to Musselburgh Grammar School, and that such a facility promotes unhealthy eating and thus would lead to harmful health consequences.ldquoThe East Lothian Local Development Plan  does not contain any policies restricting the location of drive-thru restaurant facilities to a certain distance from schools, or any other educational establishments. Nor does it contain any policies relating to unhealthy eating or the health consequences of proposed developments. Thus, and in the absence of national guidance on health consequences of proposed developments, no signicant weight can be given to these matters.The report added: ldquoOn the matter of air quality, the public health and environmental protection officer advised that the proposed development was anticipated to result in up to  customer vehicles visiting the premises daily, which was a signicant number of additional vehicles given the proximity of site to the Air Quality Management Areaon Musselburgh High Street.The officer agreed with the conclusion of McDonaldrsquos Air Quality Assessment that impacts upon air quality at ldquosensitive receptors would not be signicant. The officer advised that, whilst it was acknowledged that additional traffic would have an impact upon queuing and reduce traffic speeds, the composition of the increased traffic would be from passenger cars, which are less polluting than HGVs and buses.The officer concluded that the proposed development would have ldquono harmful impact on air quality nor on the objectives of the AQMA and would not harm the amenity of the area.A McDonaldrsquos spokesperson said: ldquoWe look forward to progressing with this application and believe a new McDonaldrsquos would bring signicant investment to the local community, as well as create at least  new jobs.A supporting statement from the company added: ldquoThere are few restaurants in the country who can claim to have made so many positive changes to support healthier lestyles. McDonaldrsquos believe that the lessons they have learned in making these changes can be used to support a wider drive to reduce obesity.Planners are recommending the plan be approved with a number of conditions, including submission of litter and pest management plans.A council spokesperson declined to comment, saying the planning committee would consider the application next week.

title: wavegarden-scotland-surf-resort-takes-step-closer-reality----looks-unreal

title: coronavirus-forces-postponement-brunton-pantomime
story: Theatre organisers were looking forward to presenting the family favourite Aladdin during the festive period.But they have taken the ldquoextremely dficult decision to postpone the show until .A Brunton spokesperson said: ldquoThe Brunton is closely following Government advice as it becomes available.ldquoThe importance of having socially distanced measures in place once live performances are able to take place again will be crucial for the safety of our customers, staff, cast and freelance creative team.ldquoThese measures will mean that the audience size for live performances at The Brunton will be vastly reduced."The live interactive family experience which The Brunton panto delivers will also be affected.Last years pantomime was Cinderella.Michael Stitt, chairman of The Brunton Theatre Trust, said: ldquoIt is with great sadness that we announce the postponement of our  pantomime.ldquoThe Brunton panto is a much-loved tradition that is central to many peoplersquos festive celebrations ndash a tradition that we enjoy bringing to le every year.ldquoWe are aware that, although this is the right decision to take, it affects many ndash the cast, crew, and creatives that make the show every year, The Brunton staff and, of course, our wonderful audiences who join us to shout out at the baddies and laugh along with the dame.ldquoSo letrsquos think of it merely as a postponement, not a cancellation, of our treasured panto. Aladdin will be with us bigger and better for the festive season .ldquoThank you from everyone at The Brunton for your continued support and understanding.Aladdin will run from November , , until December , .
